abstract: The Office of the United States Trade Representative released a report highlighting foreign trade barriers that could influence tariffs the president puts into effect this week.
title: Trump Administration Tallies Trade Barriers That Could Prompt Tariffs
author: By Ana Swanson

abstract: Forever 21 is bankrupt, supplanted by Shein and Temu, as fast fashion gets even faster and less sustainable.
title: The Fall of Forever 21 Means Fast Fashion Got Faster
author: By Amy Odell

abstract: At a time of resistance to environmental, social and governance goals, pension funds have become a bulwark against efforts to sideline climate risks.
title: Pension Funds Push Forward on Climate Goals Despite Backlash
author: By Eshe Nelson

abstract: Pittsburgh International Airport avoids power outages and reduces its energy costs by generating electricity on site using natural gas and solar panels.
title: How Pittsburgh’s Airport Makes Power to Avoid Heathrow-Like Outages

abstract: He once talked about the need to fight climate change. Now, he embraces Elon Musk, lavishes praise on the president and strives to stand out in a MAGA world.

author: By Lisa Friedman

abstract: One community near Phoenix is taking a “completely different” approach to development.

abstract: Nearly 500 buildings in the state capital get their heat from a clean, renewable source located deep in the ground.

abstract: Trump says one thing about toxins and does another.

abstract: The Dutch National Opera in Amsterdam has made dramatic moves to go green, from the materials it uses in productions to the food it serves.
title: Opera Has a Sustainability Problem. One Company Wants to Fix It.

abstract: The Supreme Court declined to hear an appeal in the long-running case, known as Juliana, which helped spawn legal strategies widely adapted to other lawsuits over climate.
title: A Landmark Lawsuit, Where Kids Sued America, Comes to an End
author: By Karen Zraick

abstract: A new report illustrates a concerning dynamic: Record heat last year pushed countries to use more planet-warming fossil fuels to cool things down.

abstract: All bags are not created equal when it comes to the environment. And paper might not be as green as you think.

abstract: Harold Hamm, Trump’s energy mentor, wants to take us back to the 1990s.
title: The Oil Oligarch Who Wants to Take Us Back to the 1990s

abstract: Mark Carney, who has only been prime minister for 10 days, has called for a general election to be held on April 28.

abstract: The New York Times sent a wide-ranging survey to candidates for governor of New Jersey about housing, immigration, abortion, transit, affordability, schools and climate.

abstract: Tariffs, tax credits and deregulation are among the industry’s top priorities.

abstract: A report from the World Meteorological Organization confirms that 2024 was the hottest year on record and the first year to be more than 1.5 degrees Celsius above the preindustrial era.

abstract: Despite President Trump’s rollback of climate policy, some Republicans and business leaders say clean energy can help his “energy dominance” agenda.

abstract: Renewable energy companies are shifting strategy under President Trump, emphasizing the economic benefits of low-carbon electricity.

abstract: NOAA, the nation’s leading climate science agency, may lose dozens of offices, including one that is key to the Mauna Loa Observatory in Hawaii.

abstract: Finland may soon become the first country to develop a permanent way to store spent nuclear fuel by burying it in tunnels deep underground.

abstract: Facing Trump tariff threats, governments and companies are proposing major investments in American liquefied natural gas projects.

abstract: The agency was created to protect the environment and public health, but a series of moves suggests it is transforming under President Trump.

abstract: The added capacity for the year was the most from any single source in more than two decades.

abstract: It’s a dirty job, and someone gets to do it.

author: By Somini Sengupta and Cassandra Klos

abstract: The state has emerged as a leader in building wildlife crossings, which can save animals, money and human lives.
title: Bridges and Tunnels in Colorado Are Helping Animals Commute
author: By Catrin Einhorn

abstract: A neglected parcel of land was restored by volunteers and patients at a community medical center. Along the way, their health also improved.
title: At This Clinic in Hawaii, Nature Is the Medicine
author: By Cara Buckley and Marie Eriel Hobro

abstract: Trump officials have demanded more European military spending and questioned the continent’s values. Leaked messages show the depth of the rift.
title: Now Europe Knows What Trump’s Team Calls It Behind Its Back: ‘Pathetic’
author: By Jeanna Smialek and Steven Erlanger

abstract: European universities have begun recruiting researchers who lost their jobs in the administration’s cost-cutting efforts, or are anxious over perceived threats to academic freedom.
title: As Trump’s Policies Worry Scientists, France and Others Put Out a Welcome Mat
author: By Catherine Porter

abstract: Bowing to Trump won’t protect their businesses and clients.
title: They Are America’s Most Powerful Law Firms. Their Silence Is Deafening.
author: By Deborah Pearlstein

abstract: Trump says one thing about toxins and does another.
title: ‘It Is Hard to Imagine a More Sweeping Agenda to Make Americans Less Healthy’
author: By Thomas B. Edsall

abstract: The Dutch National Opera in Amsterdam has made dramatic moves to go green, from the materials it uses in productions to the food it serves.
title: Opera Has a Sustainability Problem. One Company Wants to Fix It.
author: By Joshua Barone

abstract: For decades, scientists have abided by a 14-day boundary on their work. Now science can do more. But should it?
title: Should There Be Limits to Research on Human Embryos?
author: By Anna Louie Sussman

abstract: Mushrooms in 19th-century watercolors: The paintings of a self-taught female mycologist are featured at the New York State Museum.
title: A Fungi Pioneer’s Lifelong Work on Exhibit
author: By Alla Katsnelson

abstract: A report card from an engineering group found that American roads, ports and other infrastructure got better last year but could be hurt if federal funding is reduced.
title: U.S. Infrastructure Improves, but Cuts May Imperil Progress, Report Says
author: By Niraj Chokshi

abstract: It’s no Bondi Beach, but Pondi, or Penrith Beach, has been a welcome relief to the city’s sweltering western suburbs.
title: What Makes Sydney’s New Beach Different? It’s 50 Miles Inland.
author: By Victoria Kim

abstract: The Supreme Court declined to hear an appeal in the long-running case, known as Juliana, which helped spawn legal strategies widely adapted to other lawsuits over climate.
title: A Landmark Lawsuit, Where Kids Sued America, Comes to an End
author: By Karen Zraick

abstract: Plus, the practical magic of “speedcubing.”
title: Tuesday Briefing: Trump Threatens New Tariffs
author: By Emmett Lindner

abstract: President Trump has made no secret of his designs on Greenland, repeating threats to acquire the territory through a financial transaction or military force.
title: Why Does Trump Want Greenland? Here’s What to Know.
author: By Karoun Demirjian

abstract: Life has looked a little different for a New York Times journalist covering the U.S. auto industry — and the tech billionaire at its forefront.
title: A Driving Force Behind One Reporter’s Beat
author: By Josh Ocampo

abstract: A new report illustrates a concerning dynamic: Record heat last year pushed countries to use more planet-warming fossil fuels to cool things down.
title: The Vicious Cycle of Extreme Heat Leading to More Fossil Fuel Use
author: By Claire Brown

abstract: Artists from around the world will converge in New York this fall for a program of live spectacles, combining music, sound, sculpture and commedia dell’arte.
title: Performa 2025 Biennial Announces New Commissions
author: By Will Heinrich

abstract: All bags are not created equal when it comes to the environment. And paper might not be as green as you think.
title: What Shopping Bags Should I Use?
author: By Rachel Nuwer

abstract: Harold Hamm, Trump’s energy mentor, wants to take us back to the 1990s.
title: The Oil Oligarch Who Wants to Take Us Back to the 1990s
author: By Russell Gold

abstract: Mark Carney, who has only been prime minister for 10 days, has called for a general election to be held on April 28.
title: Canada’s Leader Calls Snap Federal Elections Amid Trump Threats
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

abstract: Readers respond to a column by Ezra Klein about the Democrats’ approach to government. Also: Domestic enemies.
title: Democrats: Still Under Construction

abstract: What is the chief justice getting at?
title: The Repercussions of Trump v. United States May Finally Be Hitting Roberts
author: By Jamelle Bouie

abstract: Gene banks are like a survivalist cache: our nation’s safeguard against all future challenges to growing the food we need.
title: Why Did Elon Musk Go After Bunkers Full of Seeds?
author: By Iago Hale and Michael Kantar

abstract: The agency will no longer shut down “any stage of energy production,” absent an imminent threat, a new memo says, and will curtail efforts to cut pollution in poorer areas.
title: E.P.A. Investigations of Severe Pollution Look Increasingly at Risk
author: By Hiroko Tabuchi

abstract: The New York Times sent a wide-ranging survey to candidates for governor of New Jersey about housing, immigration, abortion, transit, affordability, schools and climate.
title: Where Do the Candidates for New Jersey Governor Stand on the Issues?
author: By Tracey Tully

abstract: A psychiatrist and a patient respond to an article in Science Times. Also: A plea to Congress; an upside-down definition of waste, fraud and abuse.
title: Psychiatric Drugs: Getting Off vs. Staying On

abstract: We explain how Republicans are approaching taxes.
title: The Size of the Tax Cut
author: By Andrew Duehren

abstract: Vast quantities of climate and environmental information have been removed from official websites in the past months. Scientists are trying keep it available.
title: Government Science Data May Soon Be Hidden. They’re Racing to Copy It.
author: By Austyn Gaffney

abstract: Amid dizzying changes caused by a warming climate and global attention, Greenlanders don’t want to have to choose between embracing the future and honoring their heritage.
title: Greenland Races Into New Era Without Losing Grip on Inuit Traditions
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Ivor Prickett

abstract: More than 80 Teslas were damaged in Hamilton, Ontario, the police said, amid other acts of vandalism against the company owned by Elon Musk.

abstract: A Times reporter co-wrote a guide to buying a home in an era of record heat, floods and billion-dollar disasters.

abstract: A demand for the university’s administration to place the Middle Eastern studies department under receivership could signal a broader crackdown across the United States.
title: Why Trump’s Ultimatum to Columbia Could Upend Higher Education

abstract: When it comes to fashion models, the body diversity revolution appears to be at an end.
title: Why Ultrathin Is In
author: By Vanessa Friedman

abstract: Ms. Coventry, a former Olympic swimming champion who has been Zimbabwe’s sports minister, faces urgent issues including the rights of transgender athletes and the challenges posed by the climate crisis.
title: Kirsty Coventry Will Lead Olympics as I.O.C.’s First Female President
author: By Tariq Panja

abstract: President Trump and state politicians are pushing new laws and policies that crack down on curriculum, protests and speakers.
title: How the G.O.P. Went From Championing Campus Free Speech to Fighting It
author: By Jeremy W. Peters

abstract: Strip searches are traumatic and ineffective. It’s time to phase them out.
title: Why Are We Still Strip-Searching Prisoners?
author: By Christopher Blackwell and Sarah Sax

abstract: New data from a constellation of satellites 250 miles above Earth’s surface shows how solar and wind have taken off in recent years.
title: Here’s What the Rise of Clean Energy Looks Like From Space
author: By Mira Rojanasakul

abstract: A furniture designer and her adult children share a modern mountainside compound outside of São Paulo.
title: In Brazil, a Family Found a Way to Live Together — and Apart
author: By Michael Snyder and Fabian Martinez

abstract: A step toward a truce in Ukraine.
title: Thursday Briefing
author: By Natasha Frost

abstract: The environmental group had said the lawsuit, over its role in a protest movement, could mean an end to its operations in the United States.
title: Jury Orders Greenpeace to Pay Pipeline Company More Than $660 Million
author: By Karen Zraick

abstract: Tariffs are at the heart of the tension between the White House and the central bank.
title: Trump Primed to Clash With Fed After Key Rate Decision
author: By Tony Romm

abstract: Tariffs, tax credits and deregulation are among the industry’s top priorities.
title: What Oil Executives Want From President Trump
author: By Rebecca F. Elliott

abstract: Here are some tips on how to defend your home against floodwaters, dangerous winds and wildfires.
title: Your Home Is Vulnerable to Extreme Weather. Here’s How to Protect It.
author: By Matt Yan

abstract: The participants discuss the aftermath of Hurricane Helene, the role of government in recovery efforts and more.
title: ‘What Is Government For’? 14 Hard-Hit Voters Debate a Big Question in the Era of Trump and Musk
author: By Katherine Miller, Kristen Soltis Anderson and Adrian J. Rivera

abstract: In a new book, the psychoanalyst Jamieson Webster considers how the air we share connects us to others.
title: Every Breath You Take Is Loaded With Meaning
author: By Jennifer Szalai

abstract: For less than $65, the Deutschland-Ticket lets you take a month’s worth of unlimited journeys on the country’s regional trains and local transport systems. It’s a low-cost ticket to explore.
title: 5 Stunning German Train Trips at a Bargain Price
author: By Sally McGrane

abstract: Deciding where to live has always been a high-stakes financial decision, but a changing climate makes it even more critical. This guide will get you started.
title: How to Shop for a Home That Won’t Be Upended by Climate Change
author: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard

abstract: A report from the World Meteorological Organization confirms that 2024 was the hottest year on record and the first year to be more than 1.5 degrees Celsius above the preindustrial era.
title: Earth’s 10 Hottest Years on Record Are the Last 10
author: By Delger Erdenesanaa

abstract: Representative Andrew Garbarino of New York is at the center of a Republican push to save a key part of former President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s climate agenda.
title: The Man Behind the Republican Case for Clean Energy
author: By David Gelles

abstract: Even if you’ve sidestepped symptoms for years, the sneezing and runny nose can come for you.
title: Headache? Fatigue? You Could Have Your First Case of Seasonal Allergies.

abstract: An incoming government wants to borrow much more to revamp the economy and rebuild the military. That means a change in the country’s Constitution — and its culture.
title: Germany Is Lifting a Foot Off Its ‘Debt Brake.’ Here’s Why.
author: By Jim Tankersley and Christopher F. Schuetze

abstract: Jasmine Mooney, 35, said she was put “in chains” after immigration enforcement officers flagged her visa application paperwork. The former actress was finally allowed to return to Vancouver.
title: Canadian Who Was in an ‘American Pie’ Video Says ICE Held Her for 12 Days

abstract: The Democratic pollster David Shor walks through what voter data reveals about the 2024 election — and how the American electorate is shifting.
title: Democrats Need to Face Why Trump Won
author: By Ezra Klein

abstract: Dasheeda Dawson, who helped people start dispensaries, was accused of trying to pressure a businesswoman into a relationship in exchange for a city contract.
title: N.Y.C. Cannabis Boss Resigns Amid Sexual Harassment Investigation

abstract: Also, France’s far-right leader was barred from running for office. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
title: Trump’s Advisers Battle Over Tariff Goals
author: By Matthew Cullen

abstract: He was also a key figure in raising American soccer’s profile on the world stage. Earlier, as a marketer, he saw opportunities in the football ritual of dousing coaches with Gatorade.
title: Hank Steinbrecher, Who Helped Elevate Soccer in the U.S., Dies at 77
author: By Jeré Longman

abstract: A court’s conviction of the far-right leader for embezzlement and its ban on her running for office have set off a new crisis for France.
title: Marine Le Pen Falls to the Rule of Law and a Great Battle Looms
author: By Roger Cohen

abstract: Researchers at academic institutions nationwide say that U.S. science is being dismantled.
title: Read the Letter

abstract: As deaths mount, some volunteers complained of being blocked by Myanmar’s military from reaching a rebel stronghold that was badly hit.
title: Myanmar Quake Death Toll Tops 2,000 as Help Comes Slowly for War-Torn City
author: By Sui-Lee Wee

abstract: Monday marks the deadline for Afghans sheltering in Pakistan to leave the country, with the prospect of a dangerous future in Taliban-led Afghanistan ahead.
title: Uncertainty Torments Afghan Refugees Facing Deportation From Pakistan
author: By Zia ur-Rehman

abstract: Can forest walks, cold plunges and talking to trees make you happier? An anxious American went to Helsinki to see if what she learned there could lift her spirits back home.
title: Finland Says It Can Teach Tourists to Be Happy. Challenge Accepted.
author: By Britta Lokting

abstract: Trust is very hard to build and easy to destroy. America and its partners are caught in a spiral of distrust.
title: How Trump Supercharged Distrust, Driving U.S. Allies Away
author: By Damien Cave

abstract: Each new crisis, whether over Ukraine or tariffs, has made the Italian prime minister’s balancing act that much harder.
title: As Tensions Escalate Between Trump and Europe, Meloni Is Caught in the Middle
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Emma Bubola

abstract: Forever 21 is bankrupt, supplanted by Shein and Temu, as fast fashion gets even faster and less sustainable.
title: The Fall of Forever 21 Means Fast Fashion Got Faster
author: By Amy Odell

abstract: A veteran who returned from Iraq injured and transformed, Joy Marver is now facing a crisis at home.
title: She Devoted Her Life to Serving the U.S. Then DOGE Targeted Her.
author: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff

abstract: Leaders at top-flight law firms, Columbia University and inside City Hall are weighing decisions that pit the fates of their institutions against their own reputations.
title: In the Halls of Power, Trump’s Demands Force Agonizing Choices
author: By Dionne Searcey

abstract: Advocates of higher birthrates have support in the Trump administration. But it’s unclear whether their priorities will win out.
title: They Want More Babies. Now They Have Friends in the White House.
author: By Lydia DePillis

abstract: This is the untold story of America’s hidden role in Ukrainian military operations against Russia’s invading armies.
title: The Secret History of the War in Ukraine
author: By Adam Entous

abstract: At a time of resistance to environmental, social and governance goals, pension funds have become a bulwark against efforts to sideline climate risks.

abstract: Without advance notice to Canada, the U.S. president put the auto industry into turmoil with a 25 percent tariff.

abstract: Supporters of the political opposition are finding ways to fight back after the government jailed the top political rival of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

abstract: Pittsburgh International Airport avoids power outages and reduces its energy costs by generating electricity on site using natural gas and solar panels.

abstract: The outlet has issued dozens of corrections to A.I.-generated news summaries since it started using the technology to write them this year.

author: By Katie Robertson

abstract: Atlanta’s mayor began a drive to clear homeless encampments. But when heavy equipment came to raze one, nobody noticed that Cornelius Taylor was still inside his tent.
title: In Cities’ Rush to Clear Homeless Camps, People Have Been Crushed to Death
author: By Jason DeParle

abstract: An initiative in Zambia is showing that a profit-seeking company can help rural farmers battling extreme weather breed chickens that lay more eggs.
title: Can Climate-Resilient Chickens Help Fight Poverty?
author: By Patricia Cohen and Brian Otieno

abstract: On Saturday the U.S. figure skating star became the men’s world champion for the second straight year. To get there, he had to channel his grief over losing fellow skaters in January’s D.C. plane crash.
title: Ilia Malinin Seized the Moment. But First He Had to Get Back on His Feet.

abstract: Women’s Elite Rugby, the first professional rugby 15s women’s league in the United States, kicked off this month, offering a new opportunity for athletes hoping to compete in the 2028 Summer Games in Los Angeles.
title: A Scrum of Their Own
author: By Sara Ruberg

abstract: Ezra Klein answers listener questions about the first two months of the second Trump term and the options Democrats and civil society have in response.
title: The Last 2 Months — and Next 2 Years — of U.S. Politics
author: By Ezra Klein

abstract: Rudin stepped away from show business four years ago amid reports that he had bullied assistants. He says he has “a lot more self-control” now.
title: Scott Rudin, Producer Exiled for Bad Behavior, Plans Return to Broadway

abstract: Recent airplane accidents have fueled concerns about whether young children are sufficiently protected on flights and prompted parents and caregivers to re-evaluate how, and even whether, they should fly with infants.
title: Flying With a Child on Your Lap? You Might Want to Reconsider.

abstract: Most of Elon Musk’s associates at the Department of Government Efficiency have kept a low profile. Democrats have repeatedly criticized his effort to shrink the federal government, warning that critical services will be cut.

abstract: Gauri Gupta, 17, documents a refuge for young dreamers in a Mumbai slum.

abstract: Eric Greenspan, a developer of delivery-only restaurants, is reported to be the choice as the company faces political blowback.

abstract: Learn how to cook sole meunière, the dish that made Julia Child fall in love with French food.
title: How to Make Fish, the French Way
author: By Melissa Clark

abstract: At its current rate of borrowing, the country’s debt as a share of the economy will reach 118% in 2035, the Congressional Budget Office said on Thursday.
title: U.S. Faces ‘Significant Risks’ From Debt, Analysts Say, as Trump Pursues Tax Agenda
author: By Tony Romm

abstract: Over nearly six decades, this fantastically inventive artist experimented with paint, turning it into a sculptural medium. Our critic calls his survey “scintillating and sweeping.”
title: Jazzed About Abstraction: Jack Whitten’s Show Is a Peak MoMA Moment
author: By Holland Cotter

abstract: The nonprofit Center for Art and Advocacy, designed as a steppingstone to the art world, opens a public exhibition and education space in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

abstract: In Mississippi, incarcerated trusties cleaned chicken houses, fixed cars and installed flooring for the benefit of a local sheriff and his associates, a new investigation found.

abstract: Volunteer “puppy raisers” are chipping away at a shortage of service dogs, one short-term adoption at a time.

abstract: No dog ever begs to be put on a leash. But to stay safe during walks, your dog does need to wear one. And though it may be tempting to choose a leash that gives your dog more freedom, retractable leashes can pose a threat to your pet’s safety as well as your own. For...
title: Why We Don’t Recommend Retractable Dog Leashes

abstract: With the rise of loosely moderated social media platforms, a fringe vigilante movement is experiencing a dangerous evolution.
title: Online ‘Pedophile Hunters’ Are Growing More Violent — and Going Viral
author: By Aric Toler, Neil Bedi, Aliza Aufrichtig, Joyce Ho, Natalie Reneau and Rumsey Taylor

abstract: The author of more than a dozen books and an award-winning documentary, he died in a car crash in Southern California.

abstract: The demonstrations, a rare show of dissent, appeared to have spread, reflecting frustration at the breakdown of a cease-fire with Israel. “We want to live,” said one supporter.

abstract: A growing number of travelers say they are worried about feeling unwelcome or unsafe in America and are reluctant to support the economy of a country that may be destabilizing other nations.

abstract: The president thinks popular political opposition to his policies is manufactured.

abstract: A new book by the journalist Brian Goldstone puts a spotlight on people who have jobs but no homes, whose struggles remain largely invisible.

abstract: Creative partners since they were teenagers, the comedy duo’s new series, “The Studio,” pokes fun at the Hollywood system that practically raised them.

abstract: The residents of Fanalei Island, in the Solomon Islands, say the lucrative hunts will help them buy land elsewhere and move off their sinking home.

abstract: It’s a dirty job, and someone gets to do it.

abstract: One community near Phoenix is taking a “completely different” approach to development.

abstract: The national security adviser, already embattled, is taking the brunt of the criticism. On Fox News, he said he took “full responsibility” for a journalist being included in a chat with sensitive information.

abstract: Bowing to Trump won’t protect their businesses and clients.

author: By Niraj Chokshi

abstract: A winner of top awards in his country, he drew the attention of European and American critics. The prime minister said he “made us see Norway and the world in new ways.”
title: Dag Solstad, 83, Dies; His Novels of Alienation Delighted Norwegians
author: By Adam Nossiter

abstract: After the president made A.I. dominance a top priority, tech companies changed course from a meeker approach under the Biden administration.

abstract: For months, Israelis put aside their deep rifts to fight a common enemy. Now, amid a renewed government push for power, they are battling one another.

abstract: All bags are not created equal when it comes to the environment. And paper might not be as green as you think.

title: Murphy, Eagle Who Became a Foster Dad After Incubating a Rock, Has Died

title: Canada’s Leader Calls Snap Federal Elections Amid Trump Threats

abstract: As executive editor from 1986 to 1994, he oversaw a period of financial, technological and journalistic change while lifting newsroom morale and diversifying the staff.
title: Max Frankel, Top Times Editor Who Led a Newspaper in Transition, Dies at 94
author: By Robert D. McFadden

abstract: With Bernie Sanders unlikely to run for president again and Democratic voters fuming at party leaders, many progressives see an open lane. But who will fill it?
title: As the Left Looks to 2028, It Waits on Ocasio-Cortez’s Big Decision

abstract: Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit behind “Sesame Street,” is confronting what executives have described as a “perfect storm” of problems.

abstract: Threatened with losing $400 million in federal funding, the university agreed to overhaul its protest policies and security practices.

abstract: What is the chief justice getting at?
title: The Repercussions of Trump v. United States May Finally Be Hitting Roberts

abstract: Allies say the foreign policy version of “flood the zone” is working. But critics argue that the hurry-up approach in Israel, Ukraine and Iran may not lead to stable, durable solutions to conflicts around the world.
title: Trump’s Attempts to Resolve Global Conflicts Quickly Face Diplomatic Reality

abstract: A rice mill in Ontario is among many small businesses being hit by President Trump’s tariffs and also by Canada’s retaliatory levies, putting their futures in doubt.

abstract: Over the years, the Taiwanese art world has blossomed, thanks partly to the gallerists Tina Keng and Shelly Wu, who have championed Chinese and Taiwanese artists.
title: In Taipei, a Mother and Daughter Reflect on the Island’s Art Scene

abstract: The New York Times sent a wide-ranging survey to candidates for governor of New Jersey about housing, immigration, abortion, transit, affordability, schools and climate.
title: Where Do the Candidates for New Jersey Governor Stand on the Issues?

abstract: An anti-Zionist and antisemitic tendency gains ground in a Zionist coalition.

abstract: Hear tracks by Marianne Faithfull, the Waterboys featuring Fiona Apple, Debby Friday and more.
title: Japanese Breakfast’s Shimmering Sadness, and 8 More New Songs

abstract: The initial agreement that Bryan Johnson wanted Taryn Southern to sign.

abstract: The president’s escalating conflict with federal courts is even more aggressive than what happened in countries like Hungary and Turkey, experts say.
title: ‘This Is Worse’: Trump’s Judicial Defiance Veers Beyond the Autocrat Playbook

abstract: A couple must endure a punishing evaluation process for permission to become parents in this sleek, hermetic science fiction.
title: ‘The Assessment’ Review: Meticulously Planned Parenthood

abstract: Many in higher education worry Trump’s efforts to bend academia to his will could end American leadership in research and science. Universities are not finding many allies to defend them.

abstract: New York was defiant in the face of the Trump administration’s demand that the tolling program end by Friday. Now, Washington is willing to wait a month.
title: Trump Official Pushes Congestion Pricing Deadline Back a Month

abstract: Trump’s appointees don’t believe in the concept of a public in the first place.
title: The Entire Future of American Public Health Is at Risk
author: By David Wallace-Wells

abstract: Israel said it recaptured an area from which it withdrew in the recent cease-fire, in the most significant ground operation since the truce with Hamas collapsed.
title: Israeli Ground Forces Seize Part of Gaza Corridor, Raising Pressure on Hamas
author: By Aaron Boxerman

abstract: The composer and saxophonist Yasuaki Shimizu is at home in free jazz, classical and art pop. Finally touring North America, he’s going big by staying small.
title: This Japanese Sax Polymath Might Be a Postmodern Bach

abstract: Sonia Friedman has “created her own theater studio system,” balancing big properties like “Harry Potter” and “Stranger Things” with more prestige work by Stoppard and Sondheim.

abstract: The president and his allies in Congress are targeting the financial, digital and legal machinery that powers the Democratic Party and much of the progressive political world.

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Shane Goldmacher

abstract: After 14 years between albums, the singer and fiddler has regrouped Union Station to sing about darkness and light. The group is carrying on without a key member.
title: How Alison Krauss Found the Song That Rekindled Her Distinctive Band
author: By Jon Pareles

abstract: Those who care about the world and America’s role in it need to create a new vision for how to help vulnerable people in other countries.
title: It’s Time to Reimagine Foreign Aid
author: By Farah Stockman

abstract: There are too many unanswered questions that raise suspicions.
title: I Don’t Believe a Single Word Trump and Putin Say About Ukraine
author: By Thomas L. Friedman

abstract: Changing disability allowances is a particularly contentious move within Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s center-left Labour Party.
title: Britain Aims to Cut Billions in Welfare Amid Budget Crunch
author: By Stephen Castle

abstract: New data suggests there were faults on Southern California Edison’s transmission lines early on Jan. 7 before the fire started that evening.
title: Edison’s Power Lines Were Under Strain 14 Hours Before Eaton Fire
author: By Ivan Penn and Blacki Migliozzi

abstract: Maryland is the most recent state to introduce legislation to exonerate those convicted of witchcraft centuries ago. But why now?
title: Witches Are Having a Cultural Moment. Some States Are Taking Up Their Cause.
author: By Alexander Nazaryan

abstract: Is the F.A.A. really ensuring safety by disqualifying pilots who receive a diagnosis or treatment?
title: Why Airline Pilots Feel Pushed to Hide Their Mental Illness
author: By Helen Ouyang

abstract: In “Abundance,” Ezra Klein and Derek Thompson prod fellow liberals to think beyond their despair over Trump’s return to power.
title: Can Democrats Learn to Dream Big Again?
author: By Samuel Moyn

abstract: In the novel “Theft,” by the recent Nobel laureate Abdulrazak Gurnah, three characters navigate messy relationships in 1980s Tanzania.
title: Revolution Freed Their Country, and Upended Their Lives
author: By Lauren Christensen

abstract: Days after becoming prime minister, Mark Carney visited Paris and London to highlight deep European friendships as his country fights back against President Trump’s tariffs and annexation talk.
title: ‘Most European Non-European Country’: Canada Turns to Allies as Trump Threatens
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

abstract: Responses to Senator Chuck Schumer’s reversal on the stopgap spending bill. Also: A Trump threat to law firms; the risk of TB; theaters in peril.
title: Schumer and the Shutdown About-Face

abstract: “Soon there’ll be no enforcement,” said Representative Maxine Waters of California. “We really are going to go backward.”
title: Cuts to Housing Nonprofits Will Spur Discrimination, Democrats Say
author: By Debra Kamin

abstract: Despite President Trump’s rollback of climate policy, some Republicans and business leaders say clean energy can help his “energy dominance” agenda.
title: The Republicans Pushing Trump to Save Biden’s Clean Energy Tax Credits
author: By David Gelles

abstract: An attack on a U.N. helicopter has highlighted rising tensions in the world’s youngest country, where a seven-year-old peace deal looks ever more fragile.
title: How South Sudan Returned to the Brink of War
author: By Abdi Latif Dahir

abstract: A new cultural hub spurs curiosity and cultivates transformation in a place designed for transactions — the mall at the World Trade Center.
title: Getting in Touch With the Black Imagination at the Oculus
author: By Seph Rodney

abstract: At the height of the campaign, Ukrainian forces controlled some 500 square miles of Russian territory. Now they hold just a small sliver of land along the border.
title: How Ukraine’s Offensive in Russia’s Kursk Region Unraveled
author: By Marc Santora

abstract: In 2025, the idea of settling anyplace other than Mars might seem anachronistic, but the people on Ulva are pioneers.
title: What a Small Island Off the Coast of Scotland Could Teach America
author: By Ken Ilgunas

abstract: Readers weigh in on masculinity in politics. Also: Making way for corruption; when Donald Trump flouts laws; the perversion of U.S. power.
title: Mixed Messages on Masculinity

abstract: For years, the S&P 500 soared above the stock indexes of other countries. But since Trump’s inauguration, it has fallen 6 percent and is now trailing major markets in Europe and China.
title: Trump’s Moves Are Boosting Stocks … Overseas
author: By Joe Rennison

abstract: The Trump administration’s attacks on universities will lead to the permanent diminishment of vital American institutions.
title: The End of the University as We Know It
author: By Meghan O'Rourke

abstract: He once talked about the need to fight climate change. Now, he embraces Elon Musk, lavishes praise on the president and strives to stand out in a MAGA world.
title: How Lee Zeldin Went From Environmental Moderate to Dismantling the E.P.A.
author: By Lisa Friedman

abstract: The findings, which compared the firefighters’ blood samples against those taken from other firefighters after past fires, suggest unique risks to blazes that burn in populated areas.
title: L.A. Firefighters Who Fought Blazes Show Elevated Mercury and Lead Levels
author: By Maggie Astor

abstract: Across the country, in red and blue states, everyday people, local groups and government officials are making creative plans that protect the environment. This year, we’ll be telling you about them.
title: A New Series in The Times, Inspired by You
author: By Cara Buckley and Catrin Einhorn

abstract: Referring to a little-known provision, it said power plants and others could write to seek exemptions to mercury and other restrictions and that “the president will make a decision.”
title: E.P.A. Offers a Way to Avoid Clean-Air Rules: Send an Email
author: By Hiroko Tabuchi

abstract: Nearly 500 buildings in the state capital get their heat from a clean, renewable source located deep in the ground.
title: They’re in Hot Water in Idaho. Here’s Why That’s a Good Thing.
author: By Cara Buckley and Alex Hecht

abstract: A neglected parcel of land was restored by volunteers and patients at a community medical center. Along the way, their health also improved.
title: At This Clinic in Hawaii, Nature Is the Medicine
author: By Cara Buckley and Marie Eriel Hobro

abstract: Trump says one thing about toxins and does another.
title: ‘It Is Hard to Imagine a More Sweeping Agenda to Make Americans Less Healthy’
author: By Thomas B. Edsall

abstract: A new report illustrates a concerning dynamic: Record heat last year pushed countries to use more planet-warming fossil fuels to cool things down.
title: The Vicious Cycle of Extreme Heat Leading to More Fossil Fuel Use
author: By Claire Brown

abstract: Readers respond to a column by Ezra Klein about the Democrats’ approach to government. Also: Domestic enemies.
title: Democrats: Still Under Construction

abstract: The number of cases will increase, but the rates seem to be declining with every birth cohort that reaches advanced ages, researchers said.
title: Dementia May Not Always Be the Threat It Is Now. Here’s Why.
author: By Paula Span

abstract: The agency will no longer shut down “any stage of energy production,” absent an imminent threat, a new memo says, and will curtail efforts to cut pollution in poorer areas.
title: E.P.A. Investigations of Severe Pollution Look Increasingly at Risk
author: By Hiroko Tabuchi

abstract: The New York Times sent a wide-ranging survey to candidates for governor of New Jersey about housing, immigration, abortion, transit, affordability, schools and climate.
title: Where Do the Candidates for New Jersey Governor Stand on the Issues?
author: By Tracey Tully

abstract: Greater awareness, not vaccines, has driven an increase in diagnoses.
title: I Was Diagnosed With Autism at 53. I Know Why Rates Are Rising.
author: By Holden Thorp

abstract: Tariffs, tax credits and deregulation are among the industry’s top priorities.
title: What Oil Executives Want From President Trump
author: By Rebecca F. Elliott

abstract: Even if you’ve sidestepped symptoms for years, the sneezing and runny nose can come for you.
title: Headache? Fatigue? You Could Have Your First Case of Seasonal Allergies.
author: By Mohana Ravindranath

abstract: More than 1,000 chemists, biologists and other scientists could be laid off under a plan to dismantle the Office of Research and Development.
title: Trump Administration Aims to Eliminate E.P.A.’s Scientific Research Arm
author: By Lisa Friedman

abstract: We’re unplugging the monitors of the Earth’s vital signs.
title: DOGE Is Making It Harder to Track Extreme Weather. What Could Go Wrong?
author: By Jonathan Mingle

abstract: Makoto Watanabe quit a major newspaper after it retracted a scoop. Now he runs an investigative nonprofit that does not shy away from challenging authority.
title: In Japan, a Journalist Takes a Stand by Striking Out on His Own
author: By Martin Fackler

abstract: The agency was created to protect the environment and public health, but a series of moves suggests it is transforming under President Trump.
title: The E.P.A. Shifts Its Mission
author: By Lisa Friedman and Hiroko Tabuchi

abstract: Readers make heartfelt pleas in the age of Trump. Also: The E.P.A. abandons its mission.
title: Passionate Voices in an Anguished Time

abstract: Voters are rallying behind some leaders who oppose President Trump’s tariffs, threats and insults. There’s a theory that explains why.
title: How Trump Is Helping Liberals Abroad
author: By Lauren Jackson

abstract: Lee Zeldin, the E.P.A. administrator, said the agency’s mission was to make it cheaper to buy cars, heat homes and run businesses.
title: E.P.A. Targets Dozens of Environmental Rules as It Reframes Its Purpose
author: By Lisa Friedman and Hiroko Tabuchi

abstract: Scientists collecting water, air and soil samples in neighborhoods ravaged by fires say they’re concerned about long-term health risks for residents.
title: After Wildfires, L.A.’s Clear Skies Conceal a ‘Toxic Soup’
author: By Brendan Borrell and Mark Abramson

abstract: An internal memo directs the closure of offices designed to ease the heavy pollution faced by poor and minority communities.
title: E.P.A. Plans to Close All Environmental Justice Offices
author: By Lisa Friedman

abstract: Dozens of nonprofit groups have been unable to access the federal government’s payment system. The E.P.A. hasn’t explained why.
title: E.P.A. Grant Recipients Find Their Funds Frozen, With No Explanation
author: By Claire Brown

abstract: Federal agencies are removing topsoil from burned areas but will not test it for contaminants. So scientists and residents are testing fire-affected properties themselves.
title: After the L.A. Wildfires, a Lingering Anxiety: What Is in the Soil?
author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Jesus Jiménez

abstract: Ending chronic disease requires major social change.
title: Kennedy Wants to Cure Chronic Disease. Here’s What He’s Up Against.
author: By Daniela J. Lamas

abstract: Right-wing populism thrives on scarcity. The answer is abundance. But a politics of abundance will work only if Democrats confront where their approach has failed.
title: There Is a Liberal Answer to the Trump-Musk Wrecking Ball
author: By Ezra Klein

abstract: An indefatigable gardener, she was one of the first nutritionists to emphasize the connections between farming practices and consumers’ health.
title: Joan Dye Gussow, Pioneer of Eating Locally, Is Dead at 96
author: By Joanne Kaufman

abstract: Instead of reflexively condemning tariffs, Democrats should embrace them as part of a smarter strategy to revitalize American manufacturing.
title: I’m a Rust Belt Democrat From a Swing District. Anti-Tariff Absolutism Is a Mistake.
author: By Chris Deluzio

abstract: She was the only member of the court appointed by the president to vote against his emergency request to freeze foreign aid.
title: Justice Barrett May Have the Crucial Vote in Trump Cases
author: By Adam Liptak

abstract: Since 2008, embassies and other diplomatic posts had been publishing data about local air quality. In many countries, it was the only reliable source of such information.
title: U.S. State Department Shuts Down Pollution Monitoring Abroad
author: By Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer

abstract: Bong Joon Ho has turned his funny-sad excavations of life under capitalism into unlikely blockbusters. With “Mickey 17,” he’s bending a whole new genre.
title: The ‘Parasite’ Director Brings Class Warfare to Outer Space
author: By Jonah Weiner

abstract: The Biden administration had sued to force the Denka Performance Elastomer plant in Louisiana to reduce emissions of chloroprene, a likely carcinogen.
title: Trump Administration Said to Drop Lawsuit Over Toxic Chemical
author: By Lisa Friedman

abstract: The secretary of transportation, Sean Duffy, posted an unusual video that features interviews with five men who are opposed to New York’s tolling program.
title: Trump Official Makes Video With a Message: Kill Congestion Pricing
author: By Winnie Hu
